Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (248) 975-5053.

ALLEGATION:
There are no regular afternoon staff. Staff are overworked and mandated to work
overtime without breaks.
On Pods A & B, there is often one staff supervising 17 – 20 youth.
INVESTIGATION:
DCWL received this anonymous complaint on 8/25/20 transferred from another
government department.
I interviewed Staff 1 by phone on 8/25/20. She stated there are only three regular
afternoon staff working at the facility. Staff from other shifts are randomly selected and
mandated to cover the vacant shifts. “We are mandated about once a week and hardly
ever get breaks…Our breaks are less than 15 minutes.” Staff 1 said Lincoln Center
struggles to keep staff because of frequently mandated overtime. “Staff are overworked
and not allowed to go outdoors for fresh air. I’ve complained about it.” Staff 1 added
that one staff she knows had to “work two pods at a time.” She did not know when this
happened or how many residents that staff person was monitoring. “We’re supposed to
have two staff on each pod, but there may just be one. One staff will have more than 10
residents. This only happens to the male staff.” Again, Staff 1 could not provide a date
or time that the male staff she referred to monitored more than 10 residents. She
provided me his name and I attempted to contact him. He did not return my calls.
3

Licensing rules do not regulate staff breaks and do not prohibit facilities from mandating
overtime.
I interviewed Staff 2 by phone on 8/25/20. She said she is mandated to work one to
three hours overtime “almost every day.” The shortage of staff has become worse since
the COVID pandemic. More than six months ago, she said she was asked to monitor
more than 10 residents during waking hours. Staff 2 did not remember the date this
happened.
I interviewed Staff 3 by phone on 8/26/20. For the past year, he said “security” staff
have been being pulled to the floor to work as direct care staff. “We are thrown onto the
pods every morning to make their ratio. We are not trained as youth specialists…I
informed HR of it.” Staff 3 said several security staff recently resigned because they
were tired of being “pulled to the floor.” “There are supposed to be one supervisor and
four security guards in the building. Now there is one supervisor and one security guard
on each shift.”
Rule 400.4127 (2) Staff to resident ratio indicates: At a minimum, 1 direct care worker
shall be responsible for not more than 10 residents at 1 time during residents’ normal
awake hours and nor more than 20 residents at 1 time during the residents’ normal
sleeping hours.
I interviewed CA 1. She indicated the agency’s staff to resident ratio is 2:10 during
waking hours (which translates to 1:5) and 1:10 during sleeping hours. Supervisor 1
indicated the ratio is 1:9 during waking hours and 1:10 during sleeping hours. CA 1 and
Supervisor 1’s responses were inconsistent.
I requested the agency’s written ratio policy/program statement. It indicates the
following:
1. “The ratio of direct care workers to residents during normal, non-school
waking hours, shall be no less than one worker to ten residents (2:10).
2. The normal staffing pattern will be two workers to eleven residents (2:10).
3. During normal sleeping hours, the ratio shall be one worker to eleven
residents (1:10). All Staff members are awake during this period.”
CA1 l indicated by email that CMO youth are supervised at a ratio of 1:9 and SOM JJ
youth require a ratio of 1:5. She said CMO and state-contracted youth are mixed
together on the same pods. Lincoln Center’s written policy does not indicate that ratios
differ by contract.
CA1 provided staffing records for the last two weeks of August 2020 for Pods A & B.
The records indicate there was one staff assigned to monitor 6 – 9 youth on each pod
on both day and afternoon shifts from 8/17/20 through 8/31/20. The facility staffed Pods
A & B at a ratio of 1:9 while the JJ contract requires a ratio of 1:5. The facility is within
4

the minimal licensing requirement of 1:10 but is out of compliance with the JJ
contractual requirement.
CA1 indicated there are currently 10 full-time security vacancies and 20 full-time direct
care vacancies. 14 contingent security staff and 27 contingent youth workers are
covering these shifts. CA1 said she is diligently interviewing approximately 20
candidates per week to fill these positions.
I reviewed the job description for security workers. Their normal responsibilities are as
follows:
 Controls facility entrances, visiting areas, and staff equipment issued by the
agency. Confiscates contraband from staff, visitors and residents that can be
fashioned into a weapon or used to aid in an escape.
 Operates the agency control centers (audio visual surveillance; door locking
and alarm systems, fire systems, panels for locks and in an efficient manner
attentive manner.
 Patrols assigned areas with attention to security, fire safety, and safety of all
personnel.
 Responds to all emergency situations.
 Patrols outside perimeter of facility paying special attention to fences, parking
lots, facility entrances and windows.
 Screens visitors and issue visitor’s passes.
 Prepares written reports concerning incidences of youth disturbances or
injuries.
 Maintains authority and structured supervision in all situations including
transportation.
 Follows mandatory seat belt laws and ensures that youth are shackled as
indicated in the Standard Operations Procedures Manual.
 Takes direct transportation routes and informs facility if detours must occur.
Observes conduct and behavior of youths and communicates unusual
behavior to direct service staff and management to prevent disturbances and
escapes.
 Uses appropriate care and safety when operating vehicles and handling
equipment.
5

 Completes vehicle safety and inspection forms each time a Spectrum
Juvenile Justice van is driven.
 Complies with SJJS and Spectrum program manuals and procedures
 Completes institution staff and youth headcounts at scheduled times
 Reports Youth Workers and/or Security Officers that vacate their assigned
work assignments or that fall asleep on duty.
 Pays attention to and reports evidence of forbidden activities, and emergency
situations.
 Answers facility telephones in an appropriate and courteous manner.
 Inspects locks, windows, grills, doors and gates for tampering.
 Searches youths and cells for contraband articles and weapons.
 Escorts youth within the facility and grounds.
 Attends and actively participates in all training, in-services, conferences and
meetings as required by SJJS.
 Maintains a clean professional appearance
 Does not vacate assigned post until properly relieved. Must accept mandatory
overtime.
 Performs other duties as assigned by program supervisory and executive
staff.
Prior to employment security workers sign an agreement that says Spectrum Juvenile
Justice Services reserves the right to revise or change their job duties as the need
arises. CA 1 said youth workers and security workers receive the same training and
that both are qualified to supervise groups of children per the licensing rule.
I reviewed training records for three randomly selected security staff. All three staff had
the sufficient number of training hours and annual training in Crisis Intervention - Handle
With Care indicating the training for security staff aligns with the training requirements
for direct care staff.
6

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS: Youth workers and security staff are often mandated to work
overtime. However, there was no specific evidence that this
creates a safety risk to the youth. According to agency training
records and job descriptions, security workers can be pulled to
work on the pods and are qualified to directly supervise groups
of children.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff-to-resident ratio.
(1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-
to-resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
ANALYSIS: The agency’s staff-resident ratio policy is confusing and
unclear. The written words in the policy do not match the
numerical ratios listed. For example, during school, the
words say the ratio is 1:10 but the numbers say 2:10.
During “normal” staffing patterns (presumably non-school
days), the words say 2:11 but the numbers say 2:10.
During sleeping hours, the words say 1:11 but the
numbers say 1:10. The words do not match the
numbers. The existing policy must be revised to clearly
reflect current practice and the contractual requirements
of the youth.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7

JJ Contract Non-Compliance Established
According to Lincoln Center, the ratios of staff to resident differ by contract. Lincoln
Center does not separate differently contracted youth by pods. Therefore, any pod that
houses at least one JJ youth needs to function at the contracted ratio of 1:5. Pods A
and B house a mixture of SOM JJ and COM youth. Daily from 8/17/20 – 8/31/20, one
staff supervised more than 5 youth on days and afternoons shifts on Pods A and B.
During those times, the facility was not within the JJ contracted staffing ratio.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Once an acceptable corrective action plan is received, I recommend this facility
continue its current licensing status.
